issues.text: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the status of the assessee, Seth Govindram Sugar Mills, Mahidpur Road, Proprietor Nandlal Bachhulal, Jaora, is an Association of Persons or a firm within the meaning of Section 16(1)(b) of the Income-tax Act.

issues.text: whether during the assessment year 1950-51 the assessee was a firm or an association of persons

anchor.surface_text: Indeed, the only effective question is whether during the assessment year 1950-51 the assesee was a firm or an association of persons.

issues.text: on the death of Nandlal the firm of Seth Govindram Sugar Mills was dissolved and thereafter the income of the said business could only be assessed as that of an association of persons

anchor.surface_text: The first question raised by the learned Attorney General is that on the death of Nandlal the firm of Seth Govindram Sugar Mills was dissolved and thereafter the income of the said business could only be assessed as that of an association of persons.

anchor.surface_text: One is whether the widow of Nandlal could under Hindu law be a karta of the joint Hindu family consisting of three widows and two minors.

issues.text: whether after the death of Nandlal a new partnership was entered into between the representatives of the two branches of the families, i.e., Nandlals and Bachhulals

anchor.surface_text: The next question is whether after the death of Nandlal a new partnership was entered into between the representatives of the two branches of the families, i.e., Nandlals and Bachhulals.

arguments.court_reasoning: s.31 presupposes subsisting partnership; post-death of one in two-partner firm, no partnership exists

arguments.claim: Partnership arises from contract and not from status

anchor.surface_text: Partnership, under s. 4 of the Partnership Act, is the relation between persons who have agreed to share the profits of a business carried on by all or any of them acting for all. Section 5 of the said Act says that the relation of partnership arises from contract and not from status.

arguments.claim: s.42(c) appropriately applied only to partnerships with more than two partners; two-partner firm ends automatically on death

anchor.surface_text: Section 42 c of the Partnership Act can appropriately be applied to a partnership where there are more than two partners. ... On the other hand, if one of the two partners of a firm dies, the firm automatically comes to an end

arguments.claim: Lal Ram Kumar v. Kishori Lal not applicable as did not consider applicability of s.42(c) to two partners

anchor.surface_text: The decision of the Allahabad High Court in Lal Ram Kumar v. Kishori Lal is not of any practical help ... the question of the inapplicability of s. 42 c of the Partnership Act to such a partnership was neither raised nor decided therein.

arguments.claim: Chainkaran Sidhakaran Oswal v Radhakisan not applicable for same reason

anchor.surface_text: The same criticism applies to the decision of the Nagpur High Court in Chainkaran Sidhakaran Oswal v Radhakisan Vishwnath Dixit.

arguments.claim: Mt. Sughra v. Babu correctly holds no partnership remains after death in two-partner firm

anchor.surface_text: This question was directly raised and clearly answered by a Division Bench of the Allahabad High Court in Mt. Sughra v. Babu against the legality of such a term of a contract of partnership consisting of only two partners.

arguments.claim: Narayanan v. Umayal supports that two-partner firm ends on death, no continuity

anchor.surface_text: In Narayanan v. Umayal Ramachandra lyer J., ... said much to the same effect when he observed thus if one of the partners died, there will not be any partnership existing to which the legal representatives of the deceased partner could be taken in.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: raised number decided therein. The same criticism applies to the decision of the Nagpur High Court in Chainkarcin Sidhakaran Oswal v Radhakisan Vishw

arguments.court_reasoning: No support on authority or principle for continuity without interregnum; personality does not project to heirs

arguments.claim: Widow of Nandlal could not be karta of joint Hindu family of three widows and two minors

anchor.surface_text: One is whether the widow of Nandlal could under Hindu law be a karta of the joint Hindu family consisting of three widows and two minors.

arguments.claim: Widow lacks coparcenary qualification to be manager/karta

anchor.surface_text: The Madras and Orissa High Courts held that coparcenership is a necessary qualification for the managership of a joint Hindu family and as a widow is not admittedly a coparcener, she has no legal qualifications to become the manager

arguments.claim: Nagpur High Court view on widow as karta conflicts with settled Hindu law

anchor.surface_text: The view expressed by the Madras High Court is in accordance with well settled principles of Hindu law, while that expressed by the Nagpur High Court is in direct conflict with them.

arguments.claim: Joint Hindu family cannot be partner in firm; only through karta

anchor.surface_text: A joint Hindu family as such cannot be a partner in a firm, but it may, through its karta enter into a valid partnership with a stranger or with the karta of another family.

arguments.claim: No fresh partnership deed executed between Banarsibai as guardian and Bachhulal; no evidence of partnership post-Nandlal death until Venkatlal majority

anchor.surface_text: Admittedly no fresh partnership deed was executed between Banarsibai, acting as the guardian of the minors in Nandlals branch of the family and Bachhulal.

arguments.claim: Accounts do not show Banarsibai as partner; no documents or conduct evidence she was partner

anchor.surface_text: Not a single document has been produced on behalf of the assessee which supports the assertion that Banarsibai acted as a partner or was treated by the customers of the firm as a partner.

arguments.claim: Conduct inconsistent: widows applied for court guardians, later deeds exclude Banarsibai

anchor.surface_text: After the death of Nandlal, Banarsibai and Shantibai applied to Jaora District Court for the appointment of guardians ... If Banarsibai was acting as a guardian of the minors representing the family in the business, she would not have applied for the appointment of others as guardians.

arguments.court_reasoning: Having regard to circumstances and concession

arguments.claim: For assessment year 1950-51, assessee was firm within s.16(1)(b)

anchor.surface_text: In this view, we answer the two questions referred to the High Court as under For the assessment year 1950-51 the status of the, assessee was that of a firm within the meaning of s. 16 1 b of the Income-tax Act, 1922.

holdings.text: The partnership between Nandlal and Bachhulal came to an end on the death of Nandlal on December 9, 1945.

anchor.surface_text: The result of the discussion is that the partnership between Nandlal and Bachhulal came to an end on the death of Nandlal on December 9, 1945.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Death of one partner in a two-partner firm automatically dissolves it under s.42(c) Partnership Act; clause 3 ineffective as no subsisting partnership for heir induction; supported by ss.4,5 and precedents like Mt. Sughra v. Babu.

holdings.text: Section 42(c) of the Partnership Act applies only to partnerships with more than two partners; in a two-partner firm, death causes automatic dissolution with no scope for contrary contract.

anchor.surface_text: Section 42 c  of the Partnership Act can appropriately be applied to a partnership where there are more than two partners. If one of them dies, the firm is dissolved but if there is a contract to the contrary, the surviving partners will continue the firm. On the other hand, if one of the two partners of a firm dies, the firm automatically comes to an end

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation limits s.42(c) to multi-partner firms; upholds partnership from contract (ss.4,5); distinguishes cases not addressing s.42; follows Mt. Sughra and Narayanan; rejects respondent's harmonious reading with s.31 post-dissolution.

holdings.text: A widow cannot be the karta/manager of a joint Hindu family as she is not a coparcener.

anchor.surface_text: We are clearly of the opinion that the Madras view is correct. Another principle which is also equally well settled may be noticed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Coparcenership necessary for managership; follows Madras/Orissa HCs (Radha Ammal); rejects Nagpur HC; widow guardian but not karta.

holdings.text: No new partnership existed between representatives of the two families after Nandlal's death until December 13, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: In the result we set aside that part of the finding of the High Court holding that the partnership business was carried on by the representatives of the two families after the death of Nandlal, but confirm the finding to the extent that such a partnership came into existence only after December 13, 1949.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No deed, no evidence in accounts/conduct/documents; widows sought court guardians inconsistent with partnership role; later deeds exclude Banarsibai; guardians limited jurisdiction.

holdings.text: A joint Hindu family cannot enter partnership as such; only karta can, binding family but not making members partners.

anchor.surface_text: A joint Hindu family as such cannot be a partner in a firm, but it may, through its karta enter into a valid partnership with a stranger or with the karta of another family.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Well-settled principle; cites Kshetra Mohan Sanyasi.

holdings.text: Partnership existed from December 13, 1949, between Venkatlal (representing his family) and Bachhulal after Venkatlal attained majority.

anchor.surface_text: Indeed, it was conceded in the High Court that there was a partnership from December 13, 1949, when Venkatlal attained majority. Having regard to the said circumstances and the concession, we must hold that from December 13, 1949, the business was carried on in partnership between Venkatlal, representing his branch of the family, and Bachhulal, representing his branch of the family.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Venkatlal major, signed return/application; High Court concession; no obstacle post-majority.

holdings.text: For assessment year 1950-51, assessee's status was a firm within s.16(1)(b) Income-tax Act, 1922.

anchor.surface_text: For the assessment year 1950-51 the status of the assessee was that of a firm within the meaning of s. 16 1 b of the Income-tax Act, 1922.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Partnership post-1949 covers AY 1950-51; applies s.16(1)(b) to facts.

holdings.text: Tribunal misdirected itself in law holding parties could not be regarded as partners.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal misdirected itself in law in reaching the conclusion that the parties could not be regarded as partners.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Overlooked partnership from 1949; erred on facts/law.

precedents.citation: Lal Ram Kumar v. Kishori Lal 1

anchor.surface_text: The decision of the Allahabad High Court in Lal Ram Kumar v. Kishori Lal 1 is number of any practical help to decide the present case,. There. from the companyduct of the surviving partner and the heirs of the deceased partner after the death of the said partner, the companytract between the original partners that the partnership should number be dissolved on the death of any of them was inferred.

precedents.case_name: Lal Ram Kumar v Kishori Lal
precedents.cited_proposition: contract between partners that partnership should not be dissolved on death inferred from conduct after death, even in two-partner firm

Babu 3 against the legality of such a term of a companytract of partnership companysisting of only two partners. Agarwala, J., neatly stated the principle thus

precedents.cited_proposition: in case of partnership of only two partners, no partnership remains on death of one; cannot contract to continue
precedents.cited_holding: No heir can be said to become a partner without consent; partnership arises from contract not status

anchor.surface_text: This view accords with that expressed by us earlier. In Narayanan v. Umayal 4 . Ramachandra lyer J., as he then was, said much to the same effect when he observed thus if one of the partners died, there will number be any partnership existing to which the legal representatives of the deceased partner companyld be taken in.

precedents.cited_proposition: on death of one of two partners, partnership ends; legal reps cannot be taken into existing partnership; new partnership if they join later

precedents.citation: Hansraj Manot v. Messrs. Gorak Nath Pandey 5

anchor.surface_text: But Chatterjee J., in Hansraj Manot v. Messrs. Gorak Nath Pandey 5 struck a different numbere. His reasons for the companytrary view are expressed thus Here the companytract that has been referred to s the companytract between the two partners Gorak Nath and Champalal Therefore, it cannot be said that the companytract ceased to have effect because a partner died.

precedents.case_name: Hansraj Manot v Messrs Gorak Nath Pandey
precedents.cited_proposition: original contract between two partners binds heirs automatically on death without new contract; no interregnum

Seth Laxmi Narayan Raghunathdas 1 Pandurang Dahke Pandurang Gorle 2 , The Calcutta High Court expressed the view that where the male members are minors and their natural guardian is the mother, the mother can represent the Hindu undivided family

precedents.cited_proposition: widow can be karta of joint Hindu family

anchor.surface_text: Pandurang Dahke Pandurang Gorle 2 , The Calcutta High Court expressed the view that where the male members are minors and their natural guardian is the mother, the mother can represent the Hindu undivided family for the purpose of assessment and recovery of taxes under the Income-tax Act

precedents.cited_proposition: widow can be karta of joint Hindu family

Income-tax Officer 2

precedents.cited_proposition: mother as guardian represents HUF for tax assessment

anchor.surface_text: The decision of the Orissa High Court in Budhi Jena v. Dhobai Naik 2 followed the decision of the Madras High Court in M.N. Radha Ammal v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras 2 wherein Satyanarayana Rao J., observed

precedents.cited_proposition: coparcenary necessary for karta; widow cannot be manager/karta

precedents.citation: M.N. Radha Ammal v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras 2

anchor.surface_text: followed the decision of the Madras High Court in M.N. Radha Ammal v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras 2 wherein Satyanarayana Rao J., observed The right to become a manager depends upon the fundamental fact that the person on whom the right devolved was a companyartner of the joint family

precedents.case_name: MN Radha Ammal v Commissioner of Income-tax Madras
precedents.cited_proposition: coparcenership necessary qualification for managership/karta; widow not coparcener hence cannot be manager
precedents.cited_holding: Managership creature of law; confined to male coparceners

precedents.citation: Kshetra Mohan Sanyasi Charan Sadhukhan v. C.E.P.T. 1

anchor.surface_text: This Court in Kshetra Mohan Sanyasi Charan Sadhukhan v. C.E.P.T. 1 pointed out that when two kartas of different families companystituted a partnership the other members of the families did number become partners, though the karta might be accountable to them.

precedents.case_name: Kshetra Mohan Sanyasi Charan Sadhukhan v CEPT
precedents.cited_proposition: joint Hindu family cannot be partner in firm, but karta can; other family members do not become partners

justification_sets.label: Widow as Karta under Hindu Law support
Widow as Karta under Hindu Law support
Joint Hindu Family as Partner support

outcome.relief_summary: Appeals dismissed. Part of High Court's finding set aside (partnership not continued immediately after Nandlal's death); confirmed partnership from December 13, 1949, and status as firm for assessment year 1950-51. Questions answered in favor of assessee.

High Court finding confirmed to the extent partnership existed from December 13, 1949
Question 1 answered: status is firm under s. 16(1)(b)

anchor.surface_text: Section 42 c  of the Partnership Act can appropriately be applied to a partnership where there are more than two partners. If one of them dies, the firm is dissolved but if there is a contract to the contrary, the surviving partners will continue the firm. On the other hand, if one of the two partners of a firm dies, the firm automatically comes to an end
